name: Wonder Gecko
description: It has a broad head, long legs, and a short tail. Its delicate skin is relatively colorful—dark and light spots and stripes stand out against a yellowish background. Juveniles are bright yellow with black stripes. Its toes feature a comb-like structure that aids movement in sand.
spread_note: From the Caspian Sea to western China
image_alt: Wonder gecko, photo: Petr Velenský, Prague Zoo
proportions: Length 16–18 cm, including tail 7 cm; weight up to 25 g
reproduction: Females lay 1–2 eggs; incubation lasts 1.5–3 months.
attractions: Active at night, it’s easily spotted in the wild—its eyes glow red in flashlight beams. When threatened, it lashes its tail and intimidates with a snapping sound from rubbing scales together, plus hissing or sharp noises. If caught, its delicate skin tears easily, and its tail detaches, allowing escape. During the day, it hides in deep burrows it digs itself.
breeding: One specimen was recorded in 1989; consistent breeding began in 2012 with the arrival of the first individuals of the nominate subspecies T. s. scincus.
